articles.headline: Tech Layoffs Shock Young Workers. The Older People? Not So Much.
articles.snippet: The industry’s recent job cuts have been an awakening for a generation of workers who have never experienced a cyclical crash.
articles.abstract: The industry’s recent job cuts have been an awakening for a generation of workers who have never experienced a cyclical crash.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lyft laid off 13 percent of its workers in November, Kelly Chang was shocked to find herself among the 700 people who lost their jobs at the San Francisco company.

articles.headline: Vice, a Beleaguered Avatar of New Media, Hangs a ‘For Sale’ Sign
articles.snippet: Vice, which has struggled to achieve profitability in recent years, has formed a special committee to find suitors.
articles.abstract: Vice, which has struggled to achieve profitability in recent years, has formed a special committee to find suitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Vice Media secured a new round of financing in 2017 that valued the company at $5.7 billion, Shane Smith, one of its founders, teased the potential for “hockey stick” growth and a “sexy” stock market debut.

articles.headline: Despite Red Flags, G.O.P. Backed Candidate Now Charged in Shootings
articles.snippet: “We could have picked apart this guy,” one Republican leader in New Mexico said of Solomon Peña, who is accused of organizing attacks on the homes of four Democratic officials.
articles.abstract: “We could have picked apart this guy,” one Republican leader in New Mexico said of Solomon Peña, who is accused of organizing attacks on the homes of four Democratic officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — The former Republican candidate accused of targeting the homes of Democrats in drive-by shootings had routinely called for locking up 2020 election officials in Guantánamo Bay. He promoted conspiracy theories about solar power, feminism and “the demonic theories of the Globalist Elites.” He had been demoted twice by the U.S. Navy and served nearly seven years in prison for burglary.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Maggie Astor

articles.headline: Elon Musk Says His Social Media Posts Did Not Drive Tesla’s Stock Price
articles.snippet: The chief executive of Tesla testified in a federal civil trial about a 2018 plan to take the automaker private that fizzled out.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of Tesla testified in a federal civil trial about a 2018 plan to take the automaker private that fizzled out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk testified on Friday that he was aware that he posted important information on his Twitter account about Tesla, the electric car company he runs. But he denied that his social media posts were responsible for swings in Tesla’s share price.

articles.headline: Allies Fail to Agree on Sending Tanks to Ukraine
articles.snippet: Officials tried to play down the rift. But Germany is still insisting it will not be the country to take the first step alone, for fear of incurring Moscow’s wrath.
articles.abstract: Officials tried to play down the rift. But Germany is still insisting it will not be the country to take the first step alone, for fear of incurring Moscow’s wrath.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Western defense officials meeting in Germany said on Friday that they had failed to reach an agreement for sending battle tanks to Ukraine, in a setback to Kyiv’s hopes to quickly receive weapons that President Volodymyr Zelensky has called crucial to the next phase of the war.

articles.headline: Safe at Home in Dnipro, Until a Russian Missile Struck
articles.snippet: Despite the ever-present danger of war, life in Ukraine proceeds almost normally at times. Then, suddenly, it all changes, as it did in Dnipro last weekend after a missile struck an apartment complex.
articles.abstract: Despite the ever-present danger of war, life in Ukraine proceeds almost normally at times. Then, suddenly, it all changes, as it did in Dnipro last weekend after a missile struck an apartment complex.
articles.lead_paragraph: DNIPRO, Ukraine — A Russian missile as long as a city bus was nearing the end of a roughly 300-mile flight, its 2,000-pound warhead armed to detonate on impact.

articles.headline: Most Abortion Bans Include Exceptions. In Practice, Few Are Granted.
articles.snippet: Rape victims and patients with complicated pregnancies are confronting the limits of state abortion laws.
articles.abstract: Rape victims and patients with complicated pregnancies are confronting the limits of state abortion laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rape victims and patients with complicated pregnancies are confronting the limits of state abortion laws.

articles.headline: How Charlie Javice Got JPMorgan to Pay $175 Million for … What Exactly?
articles.snippet: A young founder promised to simplify the college financial aid process. It was a compelling pitch. Especially, as now seems likely, to those with little firsthand knowledge of financial aid.
articles.abstract: A young founder promised to simplify the college financial aid process. It was a compelling pitch. Especially, as now seems likely, to those with little firsthand knowledge of financial aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: When JPMorgan Chase paid $175 million to acquire a college financial planning company called Frank in September 2021, it heralded the “unique opportunity for deeper engagement” with the five million students Frank worked with at more than 6,000 American institutions of higher education.

articles.headline: A Hit French Novel Tries to Explain Putin. Too Well, Some Critics Say.
articles.snippet: A popular novel, “The Wizard of the Kremlin,” presents a sympathetic portrait of the Russian leader, critics say, raising concerns that it might influence national policy toward the Ukraine war.
articles.abstract: A popular novel, “The Wizard of the Kremlin,” presents a sympathetic portrait of the Russian leader, critics say, raising concerns that it might influence national policy toward the Ukraine war.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are “two things that Russians require from the state: internal order and external power.”

articles.headline: Inside the Supreme Court Inquiry: Seized Phones, Affidavits and Distrust
articles.snippet: An investigation of the abortion opinion leak was meant to right the institution amid a slide in public confidence. Instead, employees say, it deepened suspicions and caused disillusionment.
articles.abstract: An investigation of the abortion opinion leak was meant to right the institution amid a slide in public confidence. Instead, employees say, it deepened suspicions and caused disillusionment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last spring and summer, employees of the Supreme Court were drawn into an investigation that turned into an uncomfortable awakening.

articles.headline: Investigators Seize More Classified Documents From Biden’s Home
articles.snippet: A team from the Justice Department conducted a 13-hour search of the president’s Wilmington residence on Friday.
articles.abstract: A team from the Justice Department conducted a 13-hour search of the president’s Wilmington residence on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Investigators for the Justice Department on Friday seized more than a half-dozen documents, some of them classified, at President Biden’s residence in Wilmington, Del., after conducting a 13-hour search of the home, the president’s personal lawyer said Saturday evening.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: Germany’s Reluctance on Tanks Stems From Its History and Its Politics
articles.snippet: A post-Nazi aversion to war and a commitment to promoting peace through engagement combines with an old fixation on Russia and a deep aversion to leading militarily.
articles.abstract: A post-Nazi aversion to war and a commitment to promoting peace through engagement combines with an old fixation on Russia and a deep aversion to leading militarily.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the defeat of Nazism, Germany has self-consciously devoted itself to promoting “peace” and integrating into a European and trans-Atlantic security order where consensus has been the byword.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Erika Solomon

articles.headline: As Deepfakes Flourish, Countries Struggle With Response
articles.snippet: Few governments have approved regulations, often because of free-speech concerns. New mandates from China could change the tone of the debate on digital forgeries.
articles.abstract: Few governments have approved regulations, often because of free-speech concerns. New mandates from China could change the tone of the debate on digital forgeries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deepfake technology — software that allows people to swap faces, voices and other characteristics to create digital forgeries — has been used in recent years to make a synthetic substitute of Elon Musk that shilled a cryptocurrency scam, to digitally “undress” more than 100,000 women on Telegram and to steal millions of dollars from companies by mimicking their executives’ voices on the phone.

articles.headline: China Needs Couples to Have More Babies: Can I.V.F. Help?
articles.snippet: China is trying urgently to address its declining population. One idea is to subsidize assisted fertility procedures, which are often a last resort for couples and out of reach for many.
articles.abstract: China is trying urgently to address its declining population. One idea is to subsidize assisted fertility procedures, which are often a last resort for couples and out of reach for many.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang

articles.headline: When Students Change Gender Identity, and Parents Don’t Know
articles.snippet: Educators are facing wrenching new tensions over whether they should tell parents when students socially transition at school.
articles.abstract: Educators are facing wrenching new tensions over whether they should tell parents when students socially transition at school.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jessica Bradshaw found out that her 15-year-old identified as transgender at school after she glimpsed a homework assignment with an unfamiliar name scrawled at the top.

articles.headline: The suspect shot and killed himself, the authorities said.
articles.snippet: The attack took place in a city just east of Los Angeles that earlier in the day had hosted a festival celebrating the eve of the Lunar New Year.
articles.abstract: The attack took place in a city just east of Los Angeles that earlier in the day had hosted a festival celebrating the eve of the Lunar New Year.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was a party to celebrate the Lunar New Year, and dance students gathered at a beloved studio in the heart of Monterey Park, Calif., once marketed as a city of dreams for Chinese immigrants newly arrived in America.
articles.byline: By Corina Knoll, Jill Cowan, Victoria Kim and Edgar Sandoval

articles.headline: The Daughter of a King, and a Legacy of Tears
articles.snippet: At Graceland, family and friends gave a royal tribute to Lisa Marie Presley, whose life at times seemed to personify the dark streak of her father’s music.
articles.abstract: At Graceland, family and friends gave a royal tribute to Lisa Marie Presley, whose life at times seemed to personify the dark streak of her father’s music.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — An hour before a gospel choir kicked off the funeral for Lisa Marie Presley on the broad lawn of Graceland, Kathy Chandler, the owner of a restaurant in Pilot Point, Texas, was ambling down Elvis Presley Boulevard with a heavy heart. She was clutching a red rose.

articles.headline: How Kevin McCarthy Forged an Ironclad Bond With Marjorie Taylor Greene
articles.snippet: The close alliance that has developed between the speaker and the hard-right Georgia Republican explains his rise, how he might govern and the heavy influence of the extremes on the new House G.O.P. majority.
articles.abstract: The close alliance that has developed between the speaker and the hard-right Georgia Republican explains his rise, how he might govern and the heavy influence of the extremes on the new House G.O.P. majority.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: China’s Mad Dash Into a Strategic Island Nation Breeds Resentment
articles.snippet: For years, Beijing has thrown its wealth and weight across the globe. But its experience in the Solomon Islands calls into question its approach to expanding its power.
articles.abstract: For years, Beijing has thrown its wealth and weight across the globe. But its experience in the Solomon Islands calls into question its approach to expanding its power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Down a dirt road outside the Solomon Islands’ capital city, past Chinese construction projects and shops where Chinese merchants sell snacks, a tribal chief tried to explain what it feels like to have a rising superpower suddenly take an interest in a poor, forgotten place desperate for development.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Matthew Abbott

articles.headline: Kroger-Albertsons Merger Faces Long Road Before Approval
articles.snippet: Consumer advocates, unions and independent grocers are against a deal that would join Kroger and Albertsons, and be lucrative for investors.
articles.abstract: Consumer advocates, unions and independent grocers are against a deal that would join Kroger and Albertsons, and be lucrative for investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the pending megamerger between Kroger and Albertsons, the two largest grocery store chains in the country, was announced in October, the companies have argued that the marriage will be good for consumers, employees and communities.

articles.headline: Inflation Is Cooling, Leaving America Asking: What Comes Next?
articles.snippet: After six months of declines, inflation seems to be turning a corner. But the road back to normal is an uncertain one.
articles.abstract: After six months of declines, inflation seems to be turning a corner. But the road back to normal is an uncertain one.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Bate, a 31-year-old transportation planner in Fort Worth, spent the middle of 2022 feeling that he was “treading water” as high gas prices, climbing food costs and the prospect of a big rent increase chipped away at his finances.

articles.headline: For Tech Companies, Years of Easy Money Yield to Hard Times
articles.snippet: Rock-bottom rates were the secret engine fueling $1 billion start-ups and virtual attempts to conquer the physical world. But in 2023, reality bites.
articles.abstract: Rock-bottom rates were the secret engine fueling $1 billion start-ups and virtual attempts to conquer the physical world. But in 2023, reality bites.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: In Moscow, a Quiet Antiwar Protest With Flowers and Plush Toys
articles.snippet: Amid Russia’s crackdown on resistance to the war in Ukraine, some have dared to lay bouquets and other offerings at a statue of a Ukrainian poet, protesting the recent Russian strike on civilians in Dnipro.
articles.abstract: Amid Russia’s crackdown on resistance to the war in Ukraine, some have dared to lay bouquets and other offerings at a statue of a Ukrainian poet, protesting the recent Russian strike on civilians in Dnipro.
articles.lead_paragraph: Police buses seem ubiquitous in Moscow since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine last February, watching over much of the city center, including a statue of one of Ukraine’s most famous poets that has become a popular spot for a silent but emotional outpouring of antiwar sentiment.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

articles.headline: Microsoft to Invest $10 Billion in OpenAI, the Creator of ChatGPT
articles.snippet: The tech giant aims to remain at the forefront of generative artificial intelligence with its partnership with OpenAI.
articles.abstract: The tech giant aims to remain at the forefront of generative artificial intelligence with its partnership with OpenAI.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Monday that it was making a “multiyear, multibillion-dollar” investment in OpenAI, the San Francisco artificial intelligence lab behind the experimental online chatbot ChatGPT.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Karen Weise
